title: 109_hr602
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Keep Our Promise to America's Military Retirees Act". Congress finds that prior to December 7, 1956, retired members of the uniformed services were led to believe they would receive fully paid lifetime health care. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit decision in Schism v. United States emphasized the need for Congress to fulfill these promises made to military members from 1941 to 1956. The first health care insurance act for military members excluded older retirees. Retired officers from World War II and Korean War era were promised free health care for life, but the court upheld the judgment against their breach-of-contract claim as Congress never ratified the promise. Only Congress can fulfill the promises made in good faith to military members from that era. Statutes enacted in 1956 allowed those who entered service on or after December 7, 1956, and retired after serving a minimum of 20 years or by reason of a service-connected disability to medical and dental care in any facility of the uniformed services. Recruiters and officers continued to mislead members about entitlement to fully paid lifetime health care despite regulations limiting medical care availability. Base closures and military medical treatment drawdowns occurred between 1988 and 1995. The failure to provide adequate health care for military retirees is hindering their ability to recommend military service as a career. While some provisions have extended coverage to older retirees, those under 65 are still lacking in healthcare support. The US should fulfill promises made to veterans and ensure high-quality healthcare for all retired uniformed service members. SEC. 3. COVERAGE OF MILITARY RETIREES UNDER THE FEDERAL EMPLOYEES HEALTH BENEFITS PROGRAM. The amendment to Section 1108 of title 10, United States Code, allows for health care coverage for retirees and dependents through the Federal Employees Health Benefits program. Eligible beneficiaries include members or former members of the uniformed services, unremarried former spouses, and dependents of deceased members. Eligible beneficiaries, including members or former members of the uniformed services, unremarried former spouses, and dependents of deceased members, may enroll in a Federal Employees Health Benefit plan for self-only or self and family coverage. They are not required to meet eligibility criteria specified in chapter 89 of title 5, except as provided in specific circumstances. Eligible beneficiaries, including members or former members of the uniformed services, may enroll in Federal Employees Health Benefits program. They can change health plans and coverage as any other beneficiary. Those enrolled cannot receive health care under other specified sections but can continue to receive care in military facilities reimbursed by the program. The Government contribution for eligible beneficiaries enrolling in a health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5 is limited. Health benefits plans must maintain separate risk pools for these beneficiaries. The Secretary of Defense will reimburse eligible beneficiaries for health care expenses under TRICARE Standard if they enroll in a health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5. The Government contribution for eligible beneficiaries enrolling in a health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5 is limited. Health benefits plans must maintain separate risk pools for these beneficiaries. The Secretary of Defense will reimburse eligible beneficiaries for health care expenses under TRICARE Standard if they enroll in a health benefits plan under chapter 89 of title 5. Chapter 89 of title 5 is amended to allow reimbursement for health care costs not covered by the health benefits plan but would have been paid by the Department of Defense under TRICARE Standard. The amendments made by this section regarding health care coverage through the Federal Employees Health Benefits program will take effect on October 1, 2005. Additionally, there will be reimbursement for TRICARE pharmacy benefits at TRICARE network pharmacy levels for certain military retirees and dependents in hardship cases. The Secretary will reimburse eligible individuals for pharmacy benefits from non-TRICARE network pharmacies if certified by a physician. Eligible individuals are those with primary coverage from another insurance plan. Additionally, certain military retirees may have their Medicare Part B premium waived. 

The Social Security Act is amended to state that eligible individuals enrolled in the program will have a monthly premium of $0. Eligible individuals include those receiving retired or retainer pay from the uniformed services before December 7, 1956, their spouses, and widows or widowers. The amendment to the Social Security Act states that eligible individuals enrolled in the program will have a monthly premium of $0 starting in January 2005. The amendment also specifies that certain military retirees are exempt from this provision. Rebates will be provided to eligible individuals using a rebate methodology established under the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. The amendment to the Social Security Act exempts certain military retirees from paying monthly premiums starting in January 2005. Rebates will be provided to eligible individuals based on a methodology established under the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003.
